Srečen konec, tat je glasbeniku vrnil violino
Glasbenik je dragoceni instrument pozabil na vlaku. Policija ne bo ukrepala.
06 Nov 2019, 18:20 by U. S.



Violina je doma, je tvitnil glasbenik.



Petnajst let že igra na to glasbilo. FOTOGRAFIJE: Stephen Morris



Bila je v belem kovčku.



Nosi ime izdelovalca.


In živela sta srečno do konca svojih dni. Stephen Morris in njegova 310 let stara violina. Tudi tako bi lahko zaključili zgodbo, ki se je začela 22. oktobra. Tistega dne se je Morris, utrujen po dolgem dnevu v snemalnem studiu, peljal z vlakom iz Londona v Orpington, na postaji Penge East izstopil s svojim kolesom, dragoceno staro violino, ki jo je izdelal mojster David Tecchler leta 1709, stala naj bi 250.000 funtov, pa pozabil na vlaku. Enainpetdesetletni Morris, ki je igral in snemal z zvezdniki Davidom Bowiejem in Steviejem Wonderjem ter U2, sodeloval pri številnih filmih, tudi Gospodarju prstanov in Jamesu Bondu, je bil razumljivo na koncu z živci, ko je naslednje jutro ugotovil, da glasbila ni.»Počutim se, kot bi bil pretepen in v podplutbah. Odkar je izginila, nisem kaj prida spal,« je dejal glasbenik, ki se je po izgubi violine počutil, kot bi mu odrezali roko. Na pomoč pri iskanju dragocenega inštrumenta je kajpak takoj priskočila britanska (prometna) policija in celo objavila posnetek varnostne kamere, na katerem je bil moški, ki naj bi vzel violino, ter ga pozvala, naj z njimi stopi v stik.


Petnajst let že igra na to glasbilo. FOTOGRAFIJE: Stephen Morris

Napredek se je zgodil prejšnji četrtek, ko je Morris na svoj profil na twitterju dobil tole sporočilo: »Prepoznal sem človeka s posnetka. Mislim, da gre za nekoga, ki ga poznam. Rad bi pomagal. Vem, kako je, če pozabiš kaj vrednega na vlaku.« V naslednjih 24 urah je Morris iz Sydenhama vzpostavil stik z moškim, ki je poslal sporočilo in za katerega so sumili, da je prav on vzel glasbilo. Moški je sam sebe imenoval Gene, kar seveda ni njegovo pravo ime, prejšnji petek se je bil pripravljen sestati z violinistom, in to na parkirišču Waitrose blizu železniške postaje Beckenham na jugovzhodu Londona. Morris se seveda z njim ni sestal sam, operacijo je vodil njegov prijatelj in nekdanji policist Mike Pannett, v bližini je bilo več policistov v civilu. »Mike je bil motor vsega skupaj,« je pozneje povedal Morris. Zgodilo se je po 22. uri: policisti so opazili, kako se Gene, moški v poznih 20 letih, bliža virtuozu, se z njim rokuje in mu preda kovček z glasbilom. »Opravičeval se je, rekel je, da mi je hotel violino predati osebno,« je dejal Morris in še, da je bilo glasbilo nedotaknjeno in uglašeno. »Ne bi se moglo končati bolje,« je bil radosten Morris in pristavil, da pravzaprav niti še ni povsem dojel, da je glasbilo dobil nazaj, da ga spet drži v rokah. In da bo proslavil z vrčkom piva.Britanska policija je sporočila, da proti moškemu ne bo ukrepala, ker je pravilno ravnal, torej stopil z glasbenikom v stik in mu vrnil glasbilo. Višji policijski inšpektor Phil Briggs je dejal, da je bilo njihovo sporočilo od začetka: »Prosimo, vrnite violino.« In še: »Bila je džentelmenska izmenjava.« 
310let je stara violina.
text:
Happy ending, the thief returned the violin to the musician
The musician forgot a valuable instrument on the train. The police will not act.
06 Nov 2019, 18:20 by U. S.



The violin is home, the musician tweeted.



He has been playing this instrument for fifteen years. PHOTOS: Stephen Morris



It was in a white suitcase.



It bears the name of the manufacturer.


And they lived happily ever after. Stephen Morris and his 310 year old violin. Even so, the story that began on October 22 could be concluded. Morris, tired after a long day at the recording studio, traveled by train from London to Orpington, got off his bike at Penge East Station, a precious old violin made by master David Tecchler in 1709, costing £ 250,000. , then forgot on the train. Morris, 35, who played and starred with David Bowie and Stevie Wonder and U2, has made numerous films, including The Lord of the Rings and James Bond, was understandably at a loss when he realized the next morning that the musical was gone. as if beaten and bruised. Since she disappeared, I haven't slept much, ”said the musician, who felt like cutting his arm off after losing his violin. The British (traffic) police immediately came to the aid of finding a valuable instrument and even posted a video of a security camera featuring a man allegedly taking a violin and urging him to contact them.


He has been playing this instrument for fifteen years. PHOTOS: Stephen Morris

The advance came last Thursday when Morris received a message on his twitter profile: "I recognized the man from the clip. I think it's about someone I know. I'd like to help. I know what it's like to forget something worthwhile on the train. ”For the next 24 hours, Morris, of Sydenham, contacted the man who sent the message and was suspected to have picked up the instrument. The man called himself Gene, which of course is not his real name, last Friday he was ready to meet the violinist at the Waitrose parking lot near Beckenham Railway in south-east London. Morris, of course, did not meet with him, the operation was managed by his friend and former police officer Mike Pannett, with several civilians nearby. "Mike was the engine of it all," Morris later said. It happened after 10pm: Police officers noticed Gene, a man in his late 20s, approaching a virtuoso, shaking hands with him and handing him a suitcase with a musical instrument. "He apologized, saying he wanted to give me the violin in person," Morris said, and the instrument was intact and tuned. "It couldn't have ended better," Morris was pleased, saying that he hadn't even fully realized that he had got the musical instrument back to hold it again. And to celebrate with a mug of beer.British police said they would not take action on the men because he had acted correctly, so he contacted the musician and returned the instrument to him. Senior Police Inspector Phil Briggs said their message was from the beginning, "Please return the violin." And further, "It was a gentleman's exchange."
